diagrams.title: OpenEMR data-flow diagram

threats.title: User credentials used for linking with actions
threats.description:
Technique: LINDDUN
Card: Linkability of Credentials 1
Description: Actions and data can be linked by re-using credentials (for multiple system interactions).

Actions and data can be linked by re-using credentials. The same username is used to maintain action logs which gives more information to link the actions and data mentioned in logs to a specific user.
threats.mitigation: A randomly generated user ID should be used instead of the user name. This will ensure that the logs do not provide any additional information about the user's actions.

threats.title: Default credentials
threats.description:
Technique: Elevation of privilege
Card: Spoofing K
Description: System ships with a default admin password and does not force a change

The default password for the "admin" user is "pass" in OpenEMR.
threats.mitigation: The system should ask to update the default password on startup

threats.title: Password entry
threats.description:
Technique: Cornucopia
Card: Authentication 3
Description: Muhammad can obtain a user's password or other secrets such as security questions, by observation during entry, or from a local cache, or from memory, or in transit, or by reading it from some unprotected location, or because it is widely known, or because it never expires, or because the user cannot change her own password

OpenEMR only provides functionality to enter text-based passwords. This opens up the opportunity for an attacker to observe the password being entered.
This threat applies to all actors in the system.
threats.mitigation: Include multiple factor authentication, and alternate methods like biometric login.

threats.title: Private RSA keys
threats.description:
Technique: Elevation of privilege
Card: Information disclosure J
Description: An attacker can discover the fixed key being used to encrypt

We have found multiple private RSA keys for OpenSSL and LDAP inside OpenEMR's GitHub repository
This threat applies to all the processes in this diagram.
threats.mitigation: The OpenEMR team needs to purge secrets from their GitHub repository and revoke secrets that were leaked.

threats.title: Invalid user input
threats.description:
Technique: Cornucopia
Card: Data validation & encoding 3
Description: Robert can input malicious data because the allowed protocol format is not being checked, or duplicates are accepted, or the structure is not being verified, or the individual data elements are not being validated for format, type, range, length and a whitelist of allowed characters or formats

In the patient demographics field, input validation can be bypassed by adding non-date values to the date of birth field, alphabetical values to phone numbers and invalid email-addresses.
threats.mitigation: Validation using allow-lists should be performed both on the client and the server side. This way, input bypassing can be prevented.

threats.title: Integer overflow
threats.description:
Technique: Cornucopia
Card: Cornucopia 2
Description: Lee can bypass application controls because dangerous/risky programming language functions have been used instead of safer alternatives, or there are type conversion errors, or because the application is unreliable when an external resource is unavailable, or there are race conditions, or there are resource initialization or allocation issues, or overflows can occur

In the patient's prescription section, while creating a new prescription, the "# of tablets" field can be given a value of "999999999999" (9 twelve times), which will lead to an integer buffer-overflow, generating a garbage value, instead of a user-entered value.
threats.mitigation: Server side validation should ensure that user input is within accepted limits.

threats.title: Formatted text and images
threats.description:
Technique: Elevation of privilege
Card: Elevation of privilege Q
Description: You include user generated content within your page, possibly including the content of random URLs

The secure chat and secure messaging features of OpenEMR include a WYSIWIG editor that allows you to create formatted text and image content.
threats.mitigation: Any form of user generated content needs to be sanitized using a globally accepted standard.

threats.title: Viewing another patients data
threats.description:
Technique: Cornucopia
Card: Authorization 6
Description: Sven can reuse a temporary password because the user does not have to change it on first use, or it has too long or no expiry, or it does not use an outof-band delivery method (e.g. post, mobile app, SMS)

One patient can view another patient's data by changing the patient's ID in the URL.
threats.mitigation: Tokens should be used to validate if a user is authorized to access the requested resource.

threats.title: Encryption of health reports
threats.description:
Technique: Cornucopia
Card: Cryptography 8
Description: Eoin can access stored business data (e.g. passwords, session identifiers, PII, cardholder data) because it is not securely encrypted or securely hashed

OpenEMR stores a lot of PII and health data for patients, which is very sensitive and should be safe-guarded using globally accepted standards.
threats.mitigation: PII and health documents should be encrypted as OpenEMR deals with a lot of health data.

threats.title: Personal documents to identify patient
threats.description:
Technique: LINDDUN
Card: Identifying Credentials 6
Description: Personal data being stored can be identified (because they are insufficiently minimized/de-identified before storage).

Personal data or documents stored on the system can identify the patient.
threats.mitigation: Personal data and documents should be encrypted using strong cryptographic algorithms.

threats.title: Heartbeat logging
threats.description:
Technique: Elevation of privilege
Card: Repudiation J
Description: An attacker can edit logs and there is no way to tell (perhaps because there is no heartbeat option for the logging system)

We did not find any heart-beat mechanisms for OpenEMRs PHP logger
threats.mitigation: The PHP logger should include a heart-beat service that ensures logging service quality

threats.title: Input bypassing
threats.description:
Technique: Elevation of privilege
Card: Tampering Q
Description: An attacker can change parameters over a trust boundary and after validation (for example, important parameters in a hidden field in HTML, or passing a pointer to critical memory)

We can create appointments for users that do not exist in OpenEMR
threats.mitigation: Server side validation should include checking if a patient actually exists before an appointment is created.

threats.title: Multiple appointments leading to DoS
threats.description:
Technique: Elevation of privilege
Card: Denial of Service K
Description: An attacker can amplify a Denial of Service attack through this component with amplification on the order of 100:1

Multiple appointments can be generated through a script which causes the UI to slow down considerably. This was also observed while fuzzing using ZAP. After this operation, the OpenEMR system takes very long to open up and respond.
threats.mitigation: There should be some CAPTCHA mechanism to limit the number of requests being made and to ensure that requests are not being made through scripts.

threats.title: Improper server configuration
threats.description:
Technique: Cornucopia
Card: Authorization 5
Description: Javier can use default, test or easily guessable credentials to authenticate, or can use an old account or an account not necessary for the application

If the Apache server is not configured correctly, an attacker could gain information of the folder structure.
This threat applies to all processes in this model.
threats.mitigation: The Apache server configurations should be verified.

diagrams.description: OpenEMR data-flow diagram that includes threats found from Elevation of Privilege, Cornucopia and LINDDUN
